item.title: Using Redis Sorted Sets for Recent User Search History
item.description: Treat recent search history as ephemeral user behavior, not core business data. Redis Sorted Sets provide a natural fit: O(log N) writes, automatic ordering, de-duplication, and bounded size—all without turning a lightweight behavior signal into a database concern.

item.title: How to Build a Modern DevOps Infrastructure Repository
item.description: A clean, layered, and cloud-native foundation for managing infrastructure both locally and in the cloud. Separates provisioning, orchestration, persistence, and automation into modular layers.

item.title: Scaling Node.js — Worker Threads & Cluster Mode
item.description: Node.js runs one event loop per process—only one CPU core is used. To scale, use Cluster for multi-process or Worker Threads for multi-thread. Both enable parallelism, but in different ways.

item.title: Async / Await Explained — What Actually Happens Under the Hood
item.description: async/await doesn’t make code run in parallel. It’s syntactic sugar over Promises that makes asynchronous logic read like synchronous flow, working by pausing and resuming execution through the event loop.

item.title: How Node.js Achieves High Concurrency on a Single CPU Core
item.description: Node.js achieves high concurrency not by multi-threading, but through its event-driven, non-blocking I/O model. It efficiently overlaps I/O waiting time across requests, allowing a single thread to handle thousands of connections.

item.title: Why OpenSearch Shouldn't Be Used as a Primary Database
item.description: OpenSearch is built for search, not for storage. Its architecture prioritizes high-performance retrieval and aggregation, not transactional integrity or consistency.

item.title: SQL in the AI Era
item.description: SQL has evolved from a query language into the data control layer of intelligent systems. Modern AI pipelines depend on reliable, interpretable, and governable access to structured data.
